title: One in eight schools don't have a library, study shows
text:
More than half of libraries were also used as a classroom for regular lessons

Pupils at one in eight schools do not have a library, a study shows.

It also found poorer children are less likely to have access to loan books than their richer peers.

Of the 1,750 schools in the survey, 13 per cent did not have a designated library space and primaries fared worse than secondaries.

Pupils at one in eight schools do not have a library, a study shows (stock image)

Nick Poole of CILIP, a library and information association, said: 'The research paints a picture of inequality of access and opportunity and insecure employment that we cannot accept.

'The findings highlight the urgency of securing national school library strategies and investment in England, Wales and Northern Ireland.'

The breakdown shows that schools in England were most likely to have a library, at 90 per cent. This fell to 67 per cent in Wales and 57 per cent in Northern Ireland. More than half of libraries were also used as a classroom for regular lessons.

The survey also shows discrepancies between rich and poor - 91% of schools that have between none and 9% of pupils eligible for free schools meals - a key measure of poverty - have a library area.

This drops to 81% among schools where 25% to 49% are eligible for free dinners, and to 56% where half or more pupils are eligible. Only 12 schools in this final category took part in the survey.

'These findings indicate that pupils in schools with a higher proportion of free school meals are less likely to experience the range of positive benefits a school library can provide,' the report said.

The survey was commissioned by the Great School Libraries campaign, which aims to ensure all children have access to books.
description: A study of 1,750 schools in the UK has found that 13 percent did not have a designated library and poorer children are less likely to have access to loan books than their wealthier peers.
